business.start.para: The PRESIDENT(Senator the Hon. Margaret Reid) took the chair at 2.00 p.m., and read prayers.

talk.start.para: —My question is to Senator Kemp, the Assistant Treasurer. Is the minister aware that the Reserve Bank confirmed in this month's statement on monetary policy that Japan's economy has been stagnating since April 1997—since the decision to increase the country's GST rate from three to five per cent? Isn't it a fact that Japan's series of income tax cuts in 1998 failed to kick-start the economy because consumers focused on the tax increase? Given the disastrous impact the GST increase had on the Japanese economy, on what basis does the Howard government assume its 10 per cent GST on virtually every good and service will not have a similar effect on the Australian economy?

—Thank you, Senator Sherry, for that question. The disaster which afflicted the Australian economy occurred with Mr Keating's recession we had to have. It was Mr Keating's policies which drove the Australian economy through the floor, which raised rates of interest—
—Tell us about the GST.

—You asked about the Australian economy and I am telling you what happened in the Australian economy. The Keating experiment resulted at times in home loan interest rates rising above 17 per cent and going north. It resulted in an unemployment level of 11.4 per cent compared with about 7.4 per cent today. Senator, the Labor Party cannot teach this government anything at all about responsible management of the economy. It is well known that there are serious problems in Japan—serious problems which have been accumulating for a long period of time. So your attempt, Senator, to claim that this was a result of a GST is, frankly, not correct.

answer.para: We are trying to carry the reform agenda onwards in the Australian economy. We are trying to move reform along a very broad front. We make no apologies for tax cuts. In your question you pointed to tax cuts in Japan as failing to stimulate the economy. Let me make it quite clear: this government makes no apology for cutting taxes. We would like to deliver to the Australian people exactly what we promised in the last election, which was, amongst other things, major tax reform, including some $13 billion of tax cuts to taxpayers.

The reforms we have in place will continue this broad thrust which has made Australia, according to one of the American economists, one of the miracle economies of the world. That came about because this government was prepared to pursue a reform agenda, the vast proportion of which was resisted at every turn by the Labor Party. Senator, let me assure you that we wish to proceed at full speed with our tax reform programs, which include a GST and major tax cuts for individuals. We wish to proceed with our reform agenda as very well articulated by Senator Alston in telecommunications and by Peter Reith in industrial relations. This government is not afraid of reform. If the Labor Party cannot assist that process, we would like them to get out of the way and allow us to do the job.

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. The point about Japan was that the income tax cuts failed to offset the particular problems with the increase in the GST which dented consumer demand. Do the Treasurer's comments that any added GST compensation would cause the economy to overheat mean that the government will not be providing any more so-called compensation, except of course to casino high rollers?

—The last comment was quite wrong, as Senator Sherry knows. There is no compensation to casino high rollers. That was quite wrong. We think our tax package is fair. It was very carefully crafted. We know that there are others in this chamber who do not feel that and we will listen very carefully to the debate as it proceeds.

—My question is to the Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Hill. Almost 400,000 new jobs have been created since the election of the Howard government and unemployment is at its lowest level since 1990. Will the minister advise the Senate of new information indicating the strength of the Australian economy and what this means for creating even more jobs and securing Australia's economic future?

—The Howard government has given sound and responsible economic management to this country. I can assure the Senate that they will get more of the same tonight: sound and responsible management. This has been recognised by others. The Australian Industry Group, in its May economic briefing, said:

answer.para: Australia is enjoying the fruits of a virtuous set of circumstances: strong economic growth, high productivity growth, low inflation, low interest rates, rising real incomes and a federal budget in surplus.

These indicators do not come around by chance. Just compare them with those under Labor for a moment. Since the recession Mr Keating gave this country—the one he said we had to have—Labor brought in a series of budget deficits: 1991-92, $13 billion deficit; 1992-93, $19 billion deficit; 1994-95, $14 billion deficit; 1995-96, $10 billion deficit. In the last two years Mr Beazley was finance minister $25 billion of deficit was his economic record, his legacy of debt to the Australian people that the Australian people have to pay for. The contrast we can be confident of tonight is that the budget will again be in surplus under this government.
As has been said by others, this economic achievement has been recognised around the world. I remind the Senate of what was said in the Wall Street Journal on Wednesday, 28 April:

Australia hasn't just avoided the Asian-Pacific downturn; it has roared ahead. While the economies of most of its Asian trading partners contracted last year, Australia's expanded 5.1 per cent, surpassing the US's 3.9 per cent pace and making it one of the fastest growing economies in the developed world.

Why was this? It was because we kept interest rates down, we took the hard decisions to reduce expenditure and we kept inflation down, giving incentive to Australian business to grow and to employ. This is being recognised by more employer organisations all the time. The Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry tells us, and I quote:
There is an increasingly optimistic outlook on the economy.

The chamber's latest survey of investor confidence shows that business confidence has reached its highest level since the survey commenced in 1991. Another survey from the Society of Certified Practising Accountants shows that 72 per cent of small business owners felt optimistic about the business environment over the next six months, with 24 per cent planning to employ more staff. That is good news for unemployed Australians. The Morgan and Banks job index survey supports this outlook, showing that, for the third consecutive quarter, levels of optimism in relation to employment growth have continued to rise. The survey shows that more than one-third of the employers surveyed are planning to increase their permanent staffing levels. Yesterday the ANZ job vacancy figures provided further confirmation, with jobs advertisements at a post-recession high—that is, since Mr Keating's recession, jobs vacancies are now at a record high.

For this government, the job is not complete. The process of reform must continue if we are to build upon the sound foundation that we have put in place in this country. As the Australian Society of Certified Practising Accountants also said, the government now needs to move ahead with the GST and other business tax reforms to ensure that it does not impede the ability of small business to continue to employ more Australians. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —My question is also directed to Senator Hill, this time in his capacity as Minister representing the Minister for Trade. It is not one of the soft dorothy dix economic questions. This is one of the hard economic questions. Let us see whether he has the courage to answer it. Can the minister confirm that the trade deficit for March—in trend terms, $1,423 million, representing an increase of $91 million over the previous month—was the fifth record deficit in succession? Why, yet again, are imports going up and exports going down? Why, in this situation, does the government continue to oppose the lifting of the $150 million cap on the Export Market Development Grants Scheme? And why is it planning to impose a GST on inbound tourism, one of our fastest growing exports?

—Obviously today is a free question time because that question would never have got through the questions commit tee. What it does is take the path of Labor's failed economic record. Senator Cook stands for increased government expenditure. What does he say? He says, `Lift the cap on the EMDG Scheme'; in other words, spend more public money. That is what Labor did in all its years in government, which gave us that huge and continuing deficit that Australians had to pay for, which pushed up interest rates and put more Australians out of work. Senator Cook has not learnt a thing. It is not surprising that he was the senator who assured the Australian people, as we went into the election in 1996, that the Australian economy was not in deficit. That is how little he understood about it, as a manager of government policy with his hands on the lever. He said to the Australian people that the accounts were not in deficit when, in fact, they were $10 billion in deficit.

answer.para: Senator Cook asks, `Why are imports continuing to grow?' The answer is simple. It is because the Australian economy is booming. People are buying. Why is it difficult to sell overseas? It is because Asia is struggling: a lot of Asian economies are struggling. What would you expect to happen? You would expect your markets to be more difficult and you would expect Australians to be buying more goods both internally and externally, and that is exactly what is happening. But the important point is that it is happening in an economic environment where we can afford for it to happen without getting into the awful mess of Labor in the run-up to the 1990 recession. Labor could not manage it because its deficits were so high. So Labor said that the only answer was to push up interest rates. It pushed up interest rates and sent small business to the wall. A million Australians become unemployed. Senator Cook, we do not need a lecture from you. Labor failed economically. That is why it was thrown out of government. This government has put in place economic management principles that can ensure ongoing prosperity and increasing employment and we are proud of it.

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I do not need a lecture from you either, Minister, about economic management. You might just try and answer this simple, straightforward question and not dodge it, for a change. See whether you can answer this question for us: how much longer does the government expect the trade balance to be in deficit at these record levels? Can you tell us how much longer our trade balance will be in deficit at these record levels? Can you answer that straight question, Minister?

—There are some hopeful signs. Not only have we diversified our exports, which I would have thought Senator Cook would applaud, but also some Asian countries are starting to come out of the recession. Korea is starting to look a bit better. As their economies strengthen, their demand for Australian goods will grow and, provided the commodity prices and other matters that are out of our control are reasonable, we will do well.
—It's up to them, not up to us.

—That is absolutely right, Senator Cook. In part, it depends upon your market. If your market is in economic failure, you do not sell your products. The point is that Labor's huge deficits were when Asia was booming. So the markets were thriving but Labor still could not produce the goods. That is why we say Labor has failed, and most Australians recognise it.

—My question is for the Assistant Treasurer, Senator Kemp. Since being elected in 1996, the coalition has managed taxpayers' money so that the government is not spending more than it earns. How has the coalition ensured that the federal government is now living within its means? Will the minister also enlighten the Senate how this fine record compares with the past government's track record in mismanaging the books?

—Thank you, Senator Synon—my Victorian colleague—for that important question. Madam President, the government living within its means, specifically in relation to the nation's finances, is something that should not be taken lightly, in our view. The Howard government respects the fact that the dollars we collect come from Australian taxpayers and we believe they have a right to know where the money is being spent and that it is being spent wisely. Our record in government so far—such as implementation of the charter of budget honesty and the pre-election fiscal outlook, as opposed to Labor's two-page press release that was their mid-year review—underpins this. What this means is that before any election Australians will be told the true financial state of the nation.

answer.para: When we came to power, the coalition said that, despite the massive deficit left by the outgoing Labor government, we will commit ourselves to balancing the budget within our first term. We achieved a budget surplus within two years. Labor left a deficit of over $10 billion when, during the 1996 election, the then government was saying to Australians that the budget was in surplus. Of the 13 budgets delivered by Labor from 1983 to 1996, nine of them were in deficit.

talk.start.para: —How many?

—Nine of them were in deficit. Nine of them spent more than the government earned and they ran up some $80 billion in debt, the interest on which we have to repay. The Labor record is appalling because Labor was prepared to spend up big and let future generations of taxpayers pay for their big spending policies.

answer.para: Leading up to tonight's budget, the Leader of the Opposition, Mr Beazley, was swanning around today saying that Labor could have produced a larger surplus than the government because it would not be giving tax cuts to the rich. In response to this rubbish, let me quote Terry McCrann in this morning's Herald Sun. He said:

Coming from the man who was deputy prime minister and/or finance minister in the Keating government that gave us $70 billion of budget deficits in just five years, that surplus claim has to be taken with a few trillion grains of salt.

McCrann also states correctly that at the last election Beazley Labor defined `rich' as people who earn $800 a week before tax. So if you earn around $600 per week after tax you are rich, according to the Labor Party, and not deserving of any tax cuts. The truth is that Labor would not have delivered a budget surplus if it were in government. They would have tried to tell Australians that spending billions of dollars more than the nation earned was living within our means. Thankfully, the country has turned its back twice now in three years on the economic irresponsibility of Labor. That is the reason why Labor is still in opposition.

talk.start.para: —My question is to Senator Alston representing the Minister for Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Business. Minister, is it a fact that the Office of the Employment Advocate is currently conducting an advertising campaign promoting Australian workplace agreements, or AWAs, which is misleading and may be in breach of section 51 of the Trade Practices Act? Can the minister confirm that the advertisement includes the line, `No employee is in any way worse off with an AWA'? Is it not a fact that many employees who sign AWAs surrender conditions such as penalty rates and overtime? Doesn't this make the advertising by the Employment Advocate misleading and deceptive?

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: —Madam President, what Senator Collins is wanting is a legal opinion. In fact, she answered her own question at the very end in any event. Whether something is misleading is not a matter for me to make a judgment about. If your question is also whether it is in breach of section 51 of the Trade Practices Act, that is a matter for others to determine; we do not make those judgments. People are entitled to approach the ACCC or take their own action. If that is the case, then no doubt you and your union friends will take the hat around once again and waste a lot more time trying to ensure that taxpayers do not understand the real benefits, and that is what it ought to be about.

answer.para: Your commitment ought not to be nitpicking, not trying to pay off your dues time and again, trying to find fault with every little thing the government does to free up the industrial relations system. What you ought to be doing is rejoicing in the fact that there is a lot more flexibility in these arrangements, that by reducing the level of requirements to be included in some of the awards, no doubt people like Senator Collins and her successors in title will probably find there is a lot less business before the commission because you will not be able to enjoy yourself as an industrial advocate to the extent that you have in the past. That is not good news for taxpayers or for workers; it is simply good for you and your union mates.

talk.start.para: —Senator, you should address your remarks to the chair.

—Madam President, what we want is a system that allows a lot more flexibility, allows workers to negotiate their own arrangements and not be distracted by scare campaigns such as the one you want to run. If you want to pay for some legal advice, I suggest you go and ask your friends to stump up with the money.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Given the Howard government's consistent performance in this area, and given the government's record of producing misleading and deceptive advertising campaigns such as the private health insurance and GST ads, when will the government live up to its responsibility to provide comprehensive and accurate information to Australian workers about their conditions of employment?

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: —We do think it is important to ensure that people are fully informed. We are not in the business of deliberately misleading people. My recollection is that Senator Ellison has responded to the health advertisements issue and pointed out that the ACCC did not find any fault with them. The trouble is that you do not want to accept the umpire's verdict. You simply want to peddle misinformation and create the impression that somehow all these advertisements and advertising campaigns are simply not justified. You had a great track record of promoting advertisements to inform the public and interested groups about initiatives taken, and you defended those to the hilt—I have forgotten the amount for the superannuation guarantee charge, but it was something close to $10 million.
—We told the truth.

—If you told the truth as you saw it, then you no doubt believed you were justified also in spending that amount of money. The amount of money that has been spent here is minuscule by comparison. (Time expired)

subdebateinfo.title: Aboriginals and Torres Strait Islanders: Stolen Generation Case

talk.start.para: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs, Senator Herron. Minister, can you confirm that a lawyer from your Office of Indigenous Policy was sent to Darwin to instruct solicitors running the Commonwealth's case against the two members of the stolen generation who are claiming damages? Minister, do you believe it is appropriate for your staff to be acting against the interests of indigenous people in this way?

talker.name: Herron, Sen John
Senator HERRON
talker.role: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

talk.start.para: —I thank Senator Woodley for the question. The government is responding to the case—that is the government's responsibility—through the Office of Indigenous Policy, for which I am responsible. Yes, I have certainly taken a keen interest in the case, and I will continue to do so because that is my responsibility on behalf of the Australian public and the government. A lawyer from the Office of Indigenous Policy went to Darwin and is following that case on my behalf. The officer reports to me so that I can take an interest in what is occurring. The case is continuing and I will keep that officer there so that the government can be informed of the events as they unfold.
—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, how much money has the government set aside to run the Commonwealth's case against the stolen children?

talker.name: Herron, Sen John
Senator HERRON
talker.role: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

talk.start.para: —The question is incorrect. The government is not running a case against the stolen children; the government is responding to the case that is currently in process and will continue to do so. In response to the specific question in relation to the cost to date, I will get the information to Senator Woodley, but it is a continuing process. It is not unusual for a government to respond to a case. The Keating government responded to similar types of cases, and the Carr government is currently responding to a similar case in New South Wales. But I am happy to find out what the current cost is and report back to Senator Woodley.

—My question is to Senator Herron, the Minister representing the Minister for Health and Aged Care. Can the minister confirm that private health insurance funds have applied for price increases averaging six per cent, which will become effective from 1 June this year? Is he aware that a typical family with a policy costing $1,700 a year who had previously been receiving the means-tested rebate saw the amount of their rebate increase from $450 to $510 under the government's most recent policy attempt? Isn't it the case that the very first premium increase after the introduction of the rebate will wipe out that $60 gain for low income families? How can the government justify the fact that low income families will be paying more in June than they were paying before the government spent $1.7 billion to make private health insurance more attractive?

talker.name: Herron, Sen John
Senator HERRON
talker.role: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

talk.start.para: —The hypocrisy of this question is breathtaking. The opposition when they were in government were the people who tried deliberately to destroy private health insurance through a number of means—they removed the private bed day subsidy and produced a 35 per cent increase in private health insurance by withdrawal of subsidies. So the hypocrisy of the question is absolutely breathtaking. What we are doing is providing incentives for people to take out private health insurance by giving a 30 per cent rebate regardless—right across the system.

answer.para: Obviously the government has a strong interest in the level of premiums charged by health insurance funds—that premiums charged are kept at an affordable level. As I have said almost ad nauseam, the cost of private health insurance will increase. We have a rapidly ageing population. We have a plethora of miraculous things being done for the ageing population: joint replacements, cardiac transplants, renal transplants and coronary bypass surgery are all occurring with a rapidly ageing population. It is inevitable, unless the honourable senator has some other solution other than socialising it, which did not work. He should stop carping about private health insurance premiums increasing. They will increase and the government is attempting to do its best to get more people into private health insurance so that the community rating principle is maintained and so that insurance premiums are kept at a minimum.

To deny a health fund a premium increase in circumstances of financial need could result in health funds closing and disruption for their members. We want the private health insurance system to continue. Health funds have only limited control over the charges set by private hospitals and doctors, and they have no control at all over the rising costs of health technologies and the effects of the ageing population.

Let me remind honourable senators that the health insurance funds have not increased premiums for over a year. That never occurred under the Labor Party when it was in government. They have been kept down for a year. We are giving everybody a 30 per cent rebate, and as increases in costs faced by health insurers occur constantly over time, the funds must pass these increases on to their members through higher premiums. There is no other alternative, and to say that the government can control this is like saying that we can stop the tide. The tide will come in whether you like it or not. We are doing our best to make sure that as many people as possible stay in private health insurance to take the pressure of the public hospital system so that we can retain Medicare.

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. From the minister's answer, I take it he is conceding that the premiums will go up from 1 June. I would be interested to know to what extent they will go up. But the question I directed to him went to the fact that premium increases will result in the advantages of the rebate being eaten away. I want to know what the government is doing about that. Low income families will be worse off than they were before the rebate if premiums go up by six per cent. I want to what know the government is doing to address that. The government says that the problem is affordability. This will make it less affordable than it was before the rebate was introduced. What are you doing to address that issue?

talker.name: Herron, Sen John
Senator HERRON
talker.role: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

talk.start.para: —I never thought I would see the day when the Labor Party would advocate private health insurance and be so concerned that people stay on. I am absolutely delighted that we have that as the official policy of the Labor Party now—to sustain private health insurance. What did the Labor Party do for compensation? Nothing!
—What is the answer?

—I will have to explain to the honourable senator: the funds take money in, they are non-profit organisations and they have to pay funds out to cover the claims, otherwise they go broke. That is the reality. We are giving a 30 per cent rebate on premiums so that we can encourage people to stay in private health insurance so that we can sustain affordability, even for people on very low incomes.

—My question without notice is to the Minister for the Environment and Heritage and relates to Basslink—the proposal to put in an undersea cable from Tasmania to Melbourne to meet the Victorian power needs mooted by 2002. Will the minister absolutely guarantee his own world heritage management plan, which prohibits either new dams on the Gordon and Franklin rivers or a rejigging of existing hydro schemes which have an adverse impact on the world heritage area and its wilderness values? Is he aware that the Tasmanian Premier overnight has stated that there will be a cofferdam as part of this proposal and that that cofferdam would affect the world heritage area, in complete breach of the minister's management plan? Will he give the Senate an assurance that no such dam will be built?

—There will be a cooperative environmental assessment process between the Commonwealth and the Tasmanian governments, and it will look at all aspects of the environmental consequences of the proposal. Obviously, the position of this government, which has a very strong record on environmental matters, will be to ensure that there is no significant environmental damage as a result of the program. The other side of the ledger, of course, that Senator Brown never considers is the very significant economic advantage that can come to Tasmania through the development of Basslink—
—And jobs.

—And the jobs that can be created as a result. This government looks for win-win outcomes, and we are not ashamed to say that. We want to see good economic outcomes and more jobs for Australians, and we want them to be created in an environmentally sustainable way. We have been able to achieve that win-win objective elsewhere, and I am confident we will be able to achieve it in this instance.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. As you will have heard, the minister for the environment has just failed to back up his own management plan for protecting the world heritage area. Is it a fact, Minister, that in 1983 the Fraser Liberal government was brought down, in part, because of its refusal to protect the Gordon and Franklin system from dams? Again I ask the minister: will you be so good as to be straight with the Senate and say that you will stand behind the world heritage management plan and that that there will be neither a dam built on the Gordon River nor the alternative proposal of diurnal flooding through the Gordon Gorge and the Gordon Splits, with the consequent environmental damage, if Basslink were to go ahead?

—I can assure Senator Brown that this government will support a good environmental outcome that is consistent with economic growth and jobs for Tasmanians. If Senator Brown is not interested in jobs for Tasmanians, that is his problem; but this government is.

subdebateinfo.title: Goods and Services Tax: Drug Treatment Services

talk.start.para: —My question is to the Assistant Treasurer, Senator Kemp. Can the minister confirm that the GST will apply to all elements of the Prime Minister's drug treatment initiative, with the sole exception of counselling services delivered by a registered health professional? Can he confirm, for example, that the 10 per cent GST will apply to residential rehabilitation, including accommodation, food and other services provided? Will the government increase its grant to compensate for the higher costs of delivering drug treatment services if the GST is introduced?

—Health costs are cut by the GST as health is zero rated. So I think the question seems to be based largely on a misconception. The issue was raised in relation to residential facilities, and the following categories of facilities will not have to charge GST for their fees: facilities that receive funding under the Aged Care Act 1997; and facilities funded by the Commonwealth, state or territory governments, where the minister for aged care determines in writing for the care and accommodation facilities. So, in relation to home and community services, there are similar criteria. We believe that we have a very good package and that people who have to use health services will certainly benefit from them.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. You did not answer the question. I talked about drug treatment facilities. Is the minister aware that pharmaceutical charges on the methadone program are up to $35 a week for dispensing methadone from chemists? Will the GST apply to these charges or will they be exempt in the same way that PBS charges are exempt?
—The GST is not applied to prescription medicines.

subdebateinfo.title: Aboriginals and Torres Strait Islanders: Welfare Dependency

talk.start.para: —My question is to the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs, Senator Herron. Our govern ment is making important progress in creating economic opportunities to encourage indigenous Australians to break free from the shackles of welfare dependency. Is the minister aware of media debate about welfare dependency, and will he outline what our government is doing to provide a better future for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders?

talker.name: Herron, Sen John
Senator HERRON
talker.role: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

talk.start.para: —I thank Senator Ferris for the question and for her continued interest in Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander affairs. She, like most of us, would be well aware of the social and economic disadvantages within the indigenous community. I was pleased to see Aboriginal leader Noel Pearson raising concerns about the effect of many, many years of welfare on his people. While indigenous Australians remain locked into welfare dependency they have no real future and will never be able to share the quality of life and standard of living their fellow Australians enjoy. I welcome Mr Pearson's comments, for they support the government's determination to encourage indigenous Australians to rid themselves of the welfare mentality fostered particularly under the last 13 years of Labor government.

answer.para: Labor actually shovelled $16,000 million out the door, but there was little improvement for indigenous Australians. Not only that, Labor paid young Australians more money to be on the dole than to be in education and training. Sadly, 60 per cent of indigenous Australians are dependent on welfare, and over 50 per cent are totally dependent. That was the legacy that we inherited.

I noticed the other day that the Beattie-Beazley message boy, Mr Wayne Swan, has miraculously seen the light. After three years of attacking our policies, Mr Swan has admitted Labor's approach was `yesterday's approach to yesterday's problem'.

talk.start.para: —He's yesterday's man.

—What hypocrisy from one of yesterday's men! Thank you, Senator MacGibbon. For the past three years, the Howard government has fostered economic empowerment among indigenous Australians through education, training, the creation of jobs and the development of successful indigenous businesses. We have also focused on the key areas of health and housing, to assist indigenous Australians to break out of the poverty cycle. We have focused on employment program assistance, traineeships and apprenticeships because they offer the best chance of permanent employment in the open labour market. When we came to office, there were just 800 indigenous trainees or apprentices. Now there are 6,000.

answer.para: Senator Stott Despoja interjecting—

talk.start.para: —I repeat: 6,000 in three years, Senator Stott Despoja, and there were 800 under the Labor Party. The number of indigenous higher education graduates grew from less than 10 in 1967 to around 1,000 in 1997, and well over 90 per cent of graduates are employed, mostly in jobs commensurate with their education. In 1972 there were only 75 indigenous Australians enrolled in higher education; last year there were 7,789.

answer.para: I think we are witnessing and are developing a number of initiatives such as Indigenous Business Australia, which will create wealth and job opportunities for many Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people. The government will announce further programs in tonight's budget which will go a long way to creating more opportunities for indigenous Australians.

A few years ago, I was in Canada and an indigenous Canadian leader made the point to me that economic development is the horse that pulls the social cart. The key to the future for indigenous economic development is independence from the welfare system.
Senator Bolkus interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Indigenous people do not want welfare, Senator Bolkus; they want economic and social independence. At the end of the day, the nation as a whole will benefit when indigenous people participate equally in the economy of this country. If you read The Penguin History of Australia , Professor Malony said that the big mistake we made as a nation was not involving our indigenous people in the economic development and wealth of this country

—My question without notice is to the Minister representing the Minister for Education, Training and Youth Affairs. How does the minister explain the decision to appoint the First Assistant Secretary of the DETYA Higher Education Division, Mr Gallagher, as chair of the inquiry into the Greenwich University bungle, when Mr Gallagher was so heavily involved in the decision to allow this dubious entity to be set up in Australia?

—Senator Carr well knows the qualifications that Mr Gallagher has in relation to higher education and the knowledge that he has about the Greenwich University issue, because he questioned him for about four hours the other day on the subject. I have made it very clear in the Senate—and so has the minister concerned—that there is an inquiry into the credentials of Greenwich University ongoing. That is nothing new; it is something that was stated at the outset and it has been discussed at the ministerial council of education ministers. There is nothing wrong with Mr Gallagher heading up this inquiry; it is entirely appropriate. In fact, if we did not have him there, we would most probably be criticised for not having involved him in the inquiry. Mr Gallagher is enormously qualified to carry out this inquiry, and it is appropriate that he be in that position.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Can the minister inform the Senate what steps were taken by DETYA when consulted by the department and/or the minister for territories to establish the bona fides of Greenwich University, either at the time Greenwich was seeking to be set up by regulation or when it sought to be established by act of the Norfolk Island legislature? Will you now confirm that the Commonwealth permitted the creation of this legally constituted university on Norfolk Island without prior assessment of the academic standing of the institution?

talk.start.para: —The information technology industries are critically important to the future of Australia. It is quite clear that what is happening on the other side is that we are going to have froth and bubble instead of any policy proposals in the lead-up to the national conference in January of next year. It is tragic that Mr McMullan went out in January this year at the National Performance Conference, admitted that Labor had been off track and said that the debate needed to be refocused. Back in April, only last month, he was out there again talking about it as though somehow, if you identify an industry, you have got a policy. Mr Beazley did it last week. You think that talking about something makes it a policy approach. Of course, it does not. —My question without notice is addressed to Senator Vanstone, the Minister for Justice and Customs. The government is strongly committed to modernising the laws that relate both to slavery and to sexual servitude. Can the minister inform the Senate of how the government's proposals for new offences relating to slavery and sexual servitude strengthen what is a national effort to stamp out this crime?

—I thank Senator Payne for her question. I am aware of reports in the Melbourne Age that a Melbourne businessman has been charged with being an unlicensed prostitution provider, living off the earnings of prostitution, false imprisonment and possessing an unregistered firearm. Trafficking in people is a developing problem throughout the world. In the sex industry, trade in people essentially involves recruiting people from one country and relocating them to another to work as prostitutes in servile or slave-like conditions for little, if any, reward. There are few countries today that are not in some way affected by the trade and, sadly, the indications are that Australia is becoming an important destination for the victims of this trade. The government is committed to modernising the law relating to slavery. We should not be relying on old imperial offences.

answer.para: The government is also committed to introducing new offences relating to sexual servitude and deceptive recruiting to protect persons who are employed as sex workers in servile conditions or deceived into working as sex workers when that was not their intention. It is interesting to note the penalties that would be incurred if someone is prosecuted under the current laws relating to prostitution. In Victoria, under the Prostitution Control Act, living on the earnings of a prostitute incurs a penalty of about four years in prison; forcing a person to provide financial support out of prostitution incurs seven years in prison. In New South Wales it is dealt with under the Summary Offences Act, but the penalty for living on the earnings of prostitution is 12 months in prison, and allowing premises to be used is also 12 months in prison. Penalties in other states are broadly similar.

However, it is important to note that the Commonwealth's Criminal Code Amendment (Slavery and Sexual Servitude) Bill 1999 provides for qualitatively different penalties. I urge members of the opposition, the Democrats and the Greens to publicly indicate their support for this bill. It is one we could get through with a minimum of fuss and demonstrate some goodwill all around, because this bill has qualitatively different penalties. It provides for penalties of up to 25 years for a person who intentionally possesses a slave and it provides for penalties of up to 15 years for the basic offence where a person causes another to enter into or remain in sexual servitude. It is an important bill. It deserves the support of everyone in this chamber and I urge them to support it as soon as we get the opportunity.

talk.start.para: —I move:

speech.para: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for the Environment and Heritage (Senator Hill) to a question without notice asked by Senator Cook today, relating to trade and the economy.

Tonight the Treasurer will be delivering the budget for Australia for the next year. One of the things we will not hear anything about is the abysmal performance of this government in terms of managing its trade account and the abysmal performance of this government in racking up levels of foreign debt that are now a record. Let us just go to three figures. Australia has the largest ever trade deficit in its history—over $10 billion of trade deficit in the year 1998. We have the largest ever current account deficit. It was over $28 billion in 1998. And we have the highest foreign debt—defined as net foreign liabilities—of over $350 billion at the current level. That is to say, this government has brought in the trifecta: the largest ever trade deficit, the largest ever current account deficit, and the largest level of foreign debt in the history of this nation. We will not hear very much from Mr Costello tonight about answers to those problems, if the answer by Senator Hill in question time today is any guide.

We ought to consider this. Australia has been a sovereign nation for 98 years. In that time we have had 35 Treasurers. Peter Costello is the 35th Treasurer of the Commonwealth of Australia. He has done what none of the other 34 could do. He has managed, as I say, the trifecta: record trade deficit, record current account deficit and record foreign debt. When we went to the election in 1996 honourable senators may remember the Liberal Party debt truck rolling through the hills and breaking down in the Blue Mountains, claiming that the Labor government at that time was making sure that foreign debt was out of control. Foreign debt is out of control and it has sky-rocketed since those days under the very government that promised it would break the back of foreign debt. It has done so. Foreign debt is reeling out of control and is now a major economic problem for the country.

When we asked the government today what they are going to do about it, what did they say? They blamed Asia as the cause of their problems. What do they otherwise say? They say that they will not spend any money to help Australian exporters develop new markets in other parts of the world to overcome the problems. We are buying more than we are selling on our external account. We are importing more than we are exporting. Imports are going up and exports are going down. The gap is widening. It cannot continue without bringing major economic problems to the domestic economy.

Let me go through the figures on the trade deficit. Not only did the trade deficit for 1998 top $10 billion but also the trade figures released last week paint a very bleak picture. In trend terms, the deficit for March was $1.4 billion, the fifth successive record monthly trade deficit ever, and exports fell and imports rose. But it gets worse. In trend terms, Australia has had a trade deficit for the past 22 months, since the middle of 1997. We have had a trade deficit since—remember these people—Geoff Prosser, John Sharp and David Jull were ministers. That is how long it has been going.

Let me turn for a moment to the balance of payments deficit. Australia's current account deficit in 1998 was over $28 billion. This represents an increase over the previous year, 1997, of 67 per cent. It is ballooning out of control. It cannot be blamed on growth either. The rate of the current account deficit to GDP is now five per cent higher than when the coalition came to office. The ratio of the current account deficit to GDP is steadily increasing. It has grown every quarter since December last year.

On foreign debt, our net foreign liabilities are now $350 billion. That not only is an all-time record but also is up more than a fifth from when the coalition was first elected in 1996. If tonight Treasurer Costello pretends that he has won the gold medal for Australia, he has in fact won the wooden spoon on the trade deficit, on the current account deficit and on our net foreign debt. There will be no cry tonight of `Gold, gold, gold, Costello!' It is the wooden spoon all the way.

talk.start.para: —It is very sad when you have to get up and respond to a former failed minister, now a tired spokesman for an opposition that have no policies of their own to advance and that have a record, whilst in government, of 13 years of abysmal economic performance. The sheer audacity of them, I have to say, is absolutely astounding. The leader under which Senator Cook serves was the finance minister of this country. For the two years that he was finance minister, the federal budget deficit racked up $24 billion worth. In other words, 25 per cent of the federal government debt that had been incurred from 1901 through to 1996 was incurred in the two years that Mr Beazley was the finance minister. Indeed, Senator Cook was a senior minister in that government, and he has the absolute audacity to come into this chamber and try to lecture and hector us about economic performance.

speech.para: The worst economic performance that any government could have is one million people unemployed. Senator Cook was the chief architect of government policy at that time under Labor. That is the worst social statistic that any country could have, and Senator Cook presided over that. Was there any mention of that today? No, because we have brought unemployment down, haven't we, to 7.4 per cent. That is the lowest it has been in the 1990s.

What about the budget deficit that Labor used to have? It is down; down to a surplus. The surplus is being used to pay off Labor's debts—the debts that people like Senator Cook racked up. They have the audacity to come into this chamber and try to tell us that somehow they have all of the economic answers. The reality is that, whilst Asia was booming, Labor was racking up budget deficit after budget deficit. Yet whilst we have been in government, Asia has been in crisis but we have been able to return budget surpluses. How have we done that? We have done that by sound economic management. As a result, interest rates have gone down, home loan affordability has gone up and small business loan affordability has gone up. As a result, employment opportunities have gone up and unemployment has come down. This is in stark contradistinction to all of those indicators whilst Labor was in government and especially while Senator Cook was parading as industry minister.

The Labor Party have a feeling that Australia is going to get another excellent Costello budget tonight so they are desperately trying to scratch around to find some sort of indicator that might take some of the gloss off the budget that will be delivered tonight. I am sure that the people who are currently in the budget lockup, from the media and elsewhere, going through the budget documentation will be more than satisfied that the budget being brought down tonight will deliver further economic recovery to this great country and will undo the damage done by Mr Beazley and Senator Cook whilst they had charge of the economic management of this country.

It is the height of audacity and duplicity for Senator Cook—with the failed past economic performance over which he presided—to come into this place and try to hector and lecture us about economic performance. We were judged at the last election on economic performance and we were re-elected. In support of that mandate given to us, we will be delivering another excellent budget this evening. I say to Senator Cook: watch this space; come into this place tonight and listen to a wonderful budget speech.

talk.start.para: —The issue that we are taking note of from question time concerns Senator Cook's question to Senator Hill, the Leader of the Government in the Senate, about the massive trade deficit for March of approximately $1.4 billion. It is interesting to note that either Senator Abetz did not listen to Senator Cook's question, because it went to trade deficit, not a budget deficit, or—
—He did not understand it.

—That is right. Senator Abetz attempted to give us a lecture about budget deficits and not trade deficits. Trade deficit concerns imports and exports. Maybe Senator Abetz does not know what it is all about. That is the issue relating to trade deficits, not budget deficits. Senator Cook asked Senator Hill about a very serious issue which goes to the fundamental future of the economy of Australia: the trade deficit. We had the second highest trade deficit on record in March and an accumulated total to date of $35 billion, or approximately 6 per cent of the economy's output. This is at a time when the economy is growing strongly. It is interesting to note that on previous occasions when we have had significant trade deficits it has been as a consequence of a drought or at a time of recession. To have a trade deficit at this time, when the economy is growing strongly, is a problem. What is going to happen when the economy grows less strongly at some point in time?

speech.para: This large deficit raises questions about the country's ability to repay debt. The Treasurer, Mr Costello, continues to maintain that the best way of sustaining and underwriting our national debt is to have a surplus on the Commonwealth budget. To that extent Senator Abetz's comments were remotely relevant. The Treasurer asserts that he does not want to add to the blow-out of the budget deficit. I will return to that point a little later. What is interesting in the latest figures is that our exports were assisted by gold sales going up by $261 million to $9.3 billion. That is before the latest decline in gold sales. We all remember that the current Treasurer, Mr Costello, touched off a decline in gold sales. Since then I notice that the Swiss and now the British have been announcing a sell-off of gold, and we certainly will not see this improved export performance in gold in the near future. It is also interesting to note that imports rose by 9.3 per cent in the nine months to March but exports rose by just 0.2 per cent. We do not hear any more about the debt truck. Remember the debt truck that the Liberal Party in opposition used to drive around? It is in the garage, and I do not think we are going to see that truck for a long time.

What are the consequences of this massive trade deficit for Australia? The reality is that to sustain that debt we have to import capital. We have to import capital in ever increasing amounts because if we do not we cannot pay for our imports. The other particular problem we have is that we have a very low, and declining, national savings level. National savings is a relevant issue; not the budget surplus but national savings is the most important issue in relation to paying for imported capital. As we have to import so much capital to meet the trade deficit, there is only one way to do that: sell off Australian assets and transfer ownership of Australian assets overseas.

In the last few weeks the Reserve Bank of Australia has warned about the consequences of and all the hoopla concerning government budget surpluses. The big problem is that government surpluses and savings have been achieved at the cost of declining household savings. This government has transferred savings from the pockets of Australians to government savings. So you have a neutral outcome in terms of total savings levels in this country, and in fact we have declining national savings. Interestingly, national savings are close to zero at the present time. For Australians to pay the ever increasing national debt, we will have to sell off our assets, increasing foreign ownership, as I have said. That is, of course, until Australian consumers run up to their debt limit, and I suspect that we are fast reaching that point. Add the impact of a GST and we will have a very unfortunate recipe for the economy when it slows. (Time expired)

speech.para: It is interesting that, when we have a discussion or questions about the economy in this place, people on the other side are always keen to jump up and quote figures that might suit their argument. But when it comes to raising issues and questions about the foreign debt that this country faces, what have they said since 1996? Very little indeed. para.inline: Report on the draft budget estimates for the Australian National Audit Office for 1999-2000.

speech.para: In accordance with the provisions of Section 53 of the Auditor-General Act 1997, the Joint Committee of Public Accounts and Audit has considered the draft budget estimates of the Australian National Audit Office for the 1999-2000 financial year.

The Committee is able to advise the Parliament that it is satisfied that the draft budget estimates submitted by the Auditor-General to the Committee on 24 March 1999 are sufficient to enable the Auditor-General to properly exercise his functions and powers under the Act, covering financial statements, performance audits, and audit services.

In his submission the Auditor-General noted that the ANAO's total cash budget appropriation in 1998-99 was $53.8 million and that no Additional Estimates funding had been sought. 1998-9 budget allocations were used to fund strategically important projects such as restructuring, computer replacements and enhancements to the ANAO's Financial Management and Human Resource Management Systems.

The Auditor General told the Committee that there were a number of significant changes to the environment in which the 1999-2000 Budget and forward estimates were constructed, the most important of these being the implementation of an accrual budgeting framework for the Commonwealth to take effect with the 1999-2000 Budget. The ANAO has for some years been costing its products on an accrual basis and is well placed to move to an accrual based budget. The ANAO has also implemented, with effect from 1 July 1998, a new Financial Management Information System to support the revised financial management framework.

The implementation of accrual budgeting is accompanied by the introduction of an Outcomes and Outputs structure which will replace the existing program structures. The new framework places a particular focus on the outputs, or goods and services produced by agencies, and the links between them and the desired outcomes of Government activity. The ANAO's outputs are defined as follows:
1. Performance Audit Services
2. Information Support Services
3. Assurance Audit Services.
The key elements of ANAO's business as summarised in the Auditor-General's submission are:
. Running costs account for the significant majority of ANAO resources;
. Property operating expenses, covered by a Memorandum of Understanding with the Department of Finance, are included in running costs;

. under the accrual budgeting environment, the previous system of annual appropriations for agencies will be replaced by appropriations for Departmental items and appropriations for Administered items;

. for the ANAO, future appropriations will, for the most part relate to Departmental items. The Auditor-General's salary and allowances will continue to be funded by the special appropriation under the Auditor-General Act.
The total budget allocation being sought for 1999-2000 is $53.6 million.

In terms of output groups, the Performance Audit Services Output Group estimates were for $18.7 million, the Information Support Services Output Group estimates were for $1.7 million and the Assurance Audit Services Output Group estimates were for $26.6 million. Although the Auditor-General understands that carryovers will not form part of the budget parameters beyond 1999-2000, it is proposed, in line with existing practice, to maintain a strategic reserve fund which is needed to assist in the management of the ANAO's business.

The process by which the Joint Committee of Public Accounts and Audit has begun to fulfil its enhanced responsibilities under the Auditor-General Act, and the Financial Management and Accountability Act has continued to evolve during this year. It is only by the experience of deliberating on matters like the appointment of the Independent Auditor, and the approval of ANAO's draft budget estimates that the practical extent of the Committee's powers of scrutiny can be defined in a way which enhances the powers of the Parliament to keep government accountable.
(signed)
